city:
Miravale, the River Crown, rises where three braided rivers collide beneath a natural basalt arch called the Starspan. The city is tiered upon islands, embankments, and locking canals, all linked by iron-limbed bridges and oar-gates that sing when the flood comes. Its people are boatwrights and bargers, glasswrights and oath-scribes, wind-chanting watermen, rivermancers, and archivists who bind vows to brass plates and riverstone. At dusk the Starspan glows with trapped starlight and pilgrims pin votive ribbons to its pitted skin, begging it not to crack.

Founding legends claim Miravale began as a flood camp around a fallen skyfire shard that melted the river sand into a pane so wide it could mirror the moon. Six families swore a Tide-Pledge there: to share water and passage, to bind all trade to open tallies, and to seat a rotating City Chair each flood-turn. For two hundred years that pledge held, renewed in the Scriptorium of Oaths over bowls of river-water and salt. Now, drought and ambition strain it thread-thin. The Wardens of the Confluence ration flow; the Rafter's League mutters that the locks close too often; the Glasswrights' Syndicate feeds its kilns with precious driftwood and peat, casting sun-glass that fetches kings' ransoms; and the Embersleeve moves contraband beneath the Night Market Vaults where the river's old cisterns drum like whale-bellies.

Miravale depends on upland grain caravans and Skytooth ore, on salt from the Giant's Stair and tar from Blackroot Forest. It sells law (oath-binding), glass (sun-shot, mirror-smooth, shard-singing), and passage (by lock or raft). The Cobalt Collegium hums strange turbines in the Loom of Tides to keep channels breathing; the Order of the Basalt Arch prays the Starspan's fractures remain hairline; the Archivists of Vow keep the city's memory in plates of etched brass, weighing every signature against a chorus of witnesses. All the while, whispers say something in the Shattermere hums back when the city sings.

Conflicts churn beneath the surface. The Grain Compact squeezes granaries to leverage water for wheat. The Wardens have seized two Embersleeve barges and a bale of blackglass that sings at midnight. House Thalen funds restorations on the Old Aurion Aqueduct, claiming it will break the drought; the Rafter's League calls it a vanity whose flow will favor whoever owns the first sluice. And each equinox, the Order of the Basalt Arch repeats their prophecy: if the Loom of Tides ever stutters for a day and night, the Starspan will split and the river will choose its own throne.

surroundings.name: Shattermere
surroundings.description: A crater-lake north of Miravale where a star fragment slammed into the floodplain, fusing sand into mirrored shelves and glass islands. The water is unnaturally clear and rings with a tone that changes with the phases of the moon.
surroundings.legend: Riverwives tell of the Mirror-Queen, a figure beneath the surface who trades one truth for one reflection; those who dive with a sealed question may return with an answer—and a face changed forever in their own glass.
hazards: Knife-sharp glass reefs beneath the surface
Echo-sickness: a lingering hum that causes listeners to hear themselves speaking in delay
Moon-maddened eels that hunt by vibration
resources: Mirror-glass plates prized by the Glasswrights' Syndicate
Clearwater ice blocks for long-haul preservation
Starshard grit used by the Cobalt Collegium for resonance experiments
dependencies: The Sunken Glassworks contracts divers under Warden escort
Archivists of Vow embargo unlicensed retrievals to limit echo-sickness
Embersleeve skiffs smuggle blackglass slivers to the Night Market

surroundings.name: Blackroot Forest
surroundings.description: A low, misted woodland with trunks charred from ancient fires; the soil is rich with pitch and the roots are veined black as ink. The forest pools breathe blue moths each dusk.
surroundings.legend: Old charcoal-burners claim a root-wyrm sleeps coiled around a coal-heart. When the drought is deepest, it wakes and drinks shadow from the trees. Leave iron in the hollows and you will not be followed by its smoke-scent.
resources: Tar, resin, and pitch for ship and lock upkeep
Hardwood lengths for oar and bridgecraft
Blue moth silk used for vow-ink filters
dependencies: Wardens of the Confluence requisition pitch for gate-seals
The Grain Compact negotiates timber rights in exchange for water allotment
Order of the Basalt Arch maintains shrines at firebreaks to placate the forest

surroundings.name: Skytooth Ridge
surroundings.description: A saw-backed range eastward, its granite stained cobalt by veins of sky-ore. The peaks cut the weather; winds scream through teeth-like cols and griffons nest on ledges of blue stone.
surroundings.legend: Miners whisper of the Blue Heart, a crystal that fell with the same star that made Shattermere. The one who carries it can quiet storms—or call them down to shatter their enemies.
hazards: Knife-winds that can flense exposed skin
Unstable sky-ore veins prone to humming collapses
resources: Sky-ore for tools, instruments, and Collegium devices
Snowmelt for highland cisterns feeding the Old Aurion Aqueduct
dependencies: House Thalen bankrolls mines at Harn's Step
Rafter's League hauls ore on switch-raft trains
Cobalt Collegium monopolizes the refinement crucibles

surroundings.name: Giant's Stair Salt Flats
surroundings.description: A terraced expanse of glimmering salt pans stepping down toward the western bay, said to be the footprint-stairs of a sleeping giant buried under the brine. Mirage mirth spirits play along the horizon.
surroundings.legend: On mid-year solstice, a pilgrim who climbs the pans without tasting water can whisper a name into the wind and the Dead Tide will answer once, in salt and sorrow.
hazards: Heat mirages that lure travelers off terraces
resources: Fine salt for preservation and rituals
Salt-crystal lenses for telescopes and vow-inspection
Brine shrimp meal for winter feed
dependencies: The Grain Compact exchanges grain for salt quotas
Glasswrights need salt for certain kiln fluxes
Embersleeve runs illicit caravans through mirage cover

surroundings.name: Whispering Moor
surroundings.description: A low, reed-choked basin south of Miravale where the wind threads the stalks to make names and half-remembered lullabies. Old caravan ruts run like scars through the damp.
surroundings.legend: The Moor-Sibyl, a chorus of voices blown through reed-bones, will answer one question in exchange for your true name—given once, never reclaimed.
hazards: Slick mud that swallows carts to the axle
Reed-leeches that slip through boot seams
resources: Peat bricks for kilns when wood is short
dependencies: The Sunken Glassworks buys peat in drought years
Archivists of Vow send novices to test their names and courage
Order of the Basalt Arch posts ward-poles to mark safe paths

surroundings.name: Old Aurion Aqueduct
surroundings.description: A broken stone spine striding the valley from the Skytooth cisterns toward Miravale. Gargoyles perch along its length, mouths dry, catching only the occasional storm-run.
surroundings.legend: The First Chair of Miravale swore the aqueduct would never run dry while the Tide-Pledge held true. When it broke, so did the flow. Restore one, say the elders, and you restore the other.
hazards: Cracked spans that shed blocks at a breath
Dormant gargoyles that wake when fed flowing water
resources: Engineering knowledge, salvage stone, and ancient siphon valves
dependencies: House Thalen hires Collegium artificers to rebuild siphons
Wardens of the Confluence seek control clauses over any renewed flow
Rafter's League agitates for public rights-of-way along the arches

buildings.name: River Crown Citadel
buildings.description: A many-angled fortress on the central island where the three rivers braid. Its bastions straddle the primary lock-channels; banners of water-blue and brass hang over machine-gates etched with tide marks.
buildings.history: Raised after the Second Flood-War when Miravale beat back raiders by closing the locks and opening the spillways. The Tide-Pledge chairs the city here each flood-turn.
buildings.function: Seat of the City Chair, command of the Wardens, and hub of toll registers.
secrets: A hidden by-pass channel runs beneath the inner yard, mapped only on brass plates in the Scriptorium of Oaths
A vault holds the original Tide-Pledge bowl, cracked
dependencies: Wardens of the Confluence man the locks and walls
Archivists of Vow certify toll ledgers
Rafter's League petitions daily for passage priority

buildings.name: The Loom of Tides
buildings.description: An enormous hydraulic engine-house of wood, iron, and sky-ore, with waterwheels turning in sequence and singing drive-belts running like river-serpents. Glyphs and flow-runes glow faintly in the steam.
buildings.history: Built by the Cobalt Collegium atop older river mills to smooth flood crests and feed drought-time channels. Its rhythm is the city's heartbeat.
buildings.function: Regulates lock levels, powers lift-bridges, and harmonizes canal flows.
secrets: If stopped, certain wards woven into the Starspan will fray, risking fractures
A resonance chamber deep within hums the same note as the Shattermere on certain moons
dependencies: Cobalt Collegium controls its maintenance
Wardens of the Confluence operate it during crises
Order of the Basalt Arch monitors its pulse for omens

buildings.name: Sunken Glassworks
buildings.description: A maze of kilns and cooling tunnels built into a flood-proofed, partially submerged cavern beside the lower quay. The main furnace is lit by a shard of starfire suspended in chains of blue iron.
buildings.history: Founded around the original skyfire pane discovered at Miravale's camp; expanded after the Shattermere dives began bringing mirror-glass plates.
buildings.function: Produces sun-glass sheets, lenses, and mirror-ware; trains glasswright apprentices.
secrets: The starfire shard pulses when the Mirror-Queen is appeased
Blackglass waste is sold through the Night Market Vaults to fund a private militia
dependencies: Glasswrights' Syndicate manages labor and contracts
Cobalt Collegium refines sky-ore crucibles for high-temp work
Rafter's League handles fragile freight upriver and down

buildings.name: Scriptorium of Oaths
buildings.description: A temple-archive of pale stone, its halls lined with shelves of etched brass plates, riverstones incised with names, and salt bowls used to sting signatures into permanence.
buildings.history: Erected after the Tide-Pledge, expanded whenever a flood-year brought disputes. In the Third Year of Echo, it bound the Oath of Silence on the Embersleeve—an oath later broken.
buildings.function: Records and enforces vows, arbitrates contracts, and serves as a court of witness.
secrets: A hidden annex contains names of those who asked the Moor-Sibyl and paid in true names
Preceptor plates can unbind lesser oaths for a price paid in service
dependencies: Archivists of Vow lead ceremonies and maintain the registry
Order of the Basalt Arch shares custodianship of sacred name-stones
All guilds submit charters here—at least on paper

buildings.name: Night Market Vaults
buildings.description: A honeycomb of old cisterns and tunnelled galleries beneath the quay, lit by fish-oil lamps and glowmoss, where stalls open only at dusk and shutter at first light.
buildings.history: Formed when drought-years turned cisterns into empty halls; the Embersleeve claimed them with bribes and blades.
buildings.function: Trading in contraband, curios, and goods that prefer not to be tallied; auctions of mirror-oddities from the Shattermere.
secrets: A culvert opens directly into a lock spillway controlled by a hidden wheel
A shrine to the Mirror-Queen sits behind a curtain of glass beads; blood and silver are both accepted
dependencies: Embersleeve enforces market peace through fear and favors
Rafter's League captains use it to hedge against official tolls
Wardens run occasional sweeps, always a step behind

buildings.name: The Starspan (Basalt Arch) Shrine
buildings.description: The city's most ancient monument: a volcanic arch bridging the main channel, pocked with geodes and hairline cracks filled with glimmering calcite. Prayer-bells hang under its ribs.
buildings.history: Venerated since before Miravale; pre-city carvings show boats and a sky-wound. The Order of the Basalt Arch has kept vigil here for six generations.
buildings.function: Pilgrimage site, omen-reading vantage, and ceremonial gate for incoming fleets.
secrets: A fracture under the east rib resonates in sympathy with the Loom of Tides
Old carvings depict a second arch: scholars argue it fell into the riverbed long ago
dependencies: Order of the Basalt Arch guards access and reads signs
Wardens coordinate ceremonial gate-raises with the shrine
All major guilds tie their banners here during oath-renewal festivals

buildings.name: The Drowned Theater
buildings.description: An amphitheater half-submerged along the quietest canal, its lower tiers lapped by water; performers stand on floating stages and the river carries their voices like silver wire.
buildings.history: Built by House Thalen to celebrate the aqueduct's first trickle; now used to court public opinion and whisper propaganda in song.
buildings.function: Public plays, trial-by-performance, and clandestine siren concerts when the moon is thin.
secrets: A siren choir rehearses beneath the stage at midnight to test how sound changes the Shattermere's hum
Certain songs can loosen low-grade vow-lashings for the length of a performance
dependencies: House Thalen sponsors productions supporting aqueduct restoration
Rafter's League hires balladeers to mock Warden tolls
Archivists quietly record performances as civic testimony

politics.name: Wardens of the Confluence
politics.agenda: Keep the water moving, the locks secure, and the city alive through drought and flood; maintain a monopoly on emergency flow decisions.
politics.history: Formed during the Flood-Wars and formalized after the Loom of Tides came online. Their power swells whenever disaster strikes.
assets: Control keys to the Loom of Tides
rivals: Glasswrights' Syndicate (over fuel and priority water)
current_tensions: Accused of closing locks to pressure the Grain Compact into lower prices
Holding seized blackglass that sings at midnight, defying Archivist injunctions

politics.name: Glasswrights' Syndicate
politics.agenda: Control all glass production and export, secure fuel sources, and keep mirror-glass secrets out of rival hands.
politics.history: Rose from three family workshops into a cartel when the Shattermere was opened for harvesting.
allies: House Thalen (in exchange for sponsorship at the Drowned Theater)
rivals: Rafter's League (over shipping rates and breakage claims)
Wardens of the Confluence (over water allotment)
current_tensions: Kiln fuel shortages create dependence on peat from Whispering Moor
Rumors of a mirror-curse on a shipment to the eastern principalities

politics.name: Cobalt Collegium
politics.agenda: Study resonance phenomena, perfect the Loom of Tides, and unlock the safe uses of sky-ore and starshards.
politics.history: Broke from the Archivists a century ago after a debate on whether vows should bind thought-experiments.
leaders: Magister Vell of the Third Wheel
assets: Sky-ore refineries at the east quay
A library of chime-plates tuned to Shattermere notes
rivals: Archivists of Vow (jurisdiction over ethics and experimentation)
Order of the Basalt Arch (spiritual objections to the Loom's tempo)
current_tensions: Facing calls to hand over control keys during festival days
A failed experiment that woke a gargoyle on the Aqueduct

politics.name: Archivists of Vow
politics.agenda: Keep the Tide-Pledge pure, enforce sworn agreements, and ensure memory holds the city together where law cannot.
politics.history: Oldest continuous institution in Miravale, predating the city’s own name; they claim custodianship over every oath spoken within earshot of river water.
assets: Sanctified name-stones and brass plate stacks
allies: Wardens of the Confluence (in law-and-order campaigns)
current_tensions: Debating whether the Tide-Pledge is already broken in spirit
Quietly sheltering defectors who regret Embersleeve oaths

politics.name: Rafter's League
politics.type: Guild of bargemen, ferriers, and freight brokers
politics.agenda: Lower tolls, increase passage windows, and pry decision-making away from the Wardens.
politics.history: Began as a mutual-aid raft circle on a fog night when eight boats tied together for survival; grew into a negotiating bloc spanning three rivers.
assets: Maps of back-channels and seasonal shortcuts
current_tensions: Threatening a lock-sit to force emergency passage for grain barges
Funding ballads at the Drowned Theater to sway public sentiment

politics.name: Embersleeve
politics.agenda: Own the night trade, bleed the guilds without being cut, and find leverage on oath-binding to loosen their leash.
politics.history: Rose from dockside gleaners who survived on kiln-scraps; now controls the Night Market Vaults and several city functionaries by whisper and blade.
leaders: The Unbraided (an anonymous council of three)
assets: Ledgers of secrets and blackmail plates
current_tensions: A broken Oath of Silence has cursed three lieutenants with salt-blood tears
Seeking to acquire a chime-plate from the Collegium to mask oath-tones

politics.name: Order of the Basalt Arch
politics.agenda: Protect the Starspan, interpret its cracks and hums, and restrain civic hubris that might sunder the arch.
politics.history: Formed when the first hairline crack appeared after a year the Loom ran at double pace; the Order placed bells beneath the ribs to listen for stress-songs.
assets: Bell-rooms tuned to river and rock
A network of laywatchers on every bridge
current_tensions: Prophecy of the Loom's stutter causing political panic
Pressing for a ritual slow-flow day each month, opposed by merchants

politics.name: Grain Compact
politics.type: Cartel of upland farmers, millers, and granary keepers
politics.agenda: Guarantee profit and stability for grain producers, exchange grain for water and security, and restrain price shocks.
politics.history: Formed during the first drought-years when independent farms went under; the Compact now speaks with a unified voice backed by stockpile leverage.
assets: A whistle network along the aqueduct road
allies: Certain Wardens sympathetic to bread riots
current_tensions: Withholding shipments to force favorable lock schedules
Funding petitions to limit sun-glass exports during famine

politics.name: House Thalen
politics.agenda: Restore the Old Aurion Aqueduct, expand influence through infrastructure patronage, and reclaim ancestral prestige.
politics.history: One of the Tide-Pledge families; nearly ruined after a bad flood gamble. Rebuilt fortunes through theater and mining investments.
current_tensions: Accused of skimming future water claims in aqueduct charters
Courting the Archivists to bless a new Oath of Flow—opposed by the Order of the Basalt Arch
